title: "What is the Relationship Between Trance States and our Natural State of Being?"
first_phrase: This text explores the concept of trance state and its relationship to our thoughts, emotions, and actions. It discusses how we often lose ourselves in our tasks and decisions, becoming identified with them rather than allowing them to flow through us. From the perspective of the human potential movement, neurosis is caused by an interruption in the outward flow of emotion. The text also draws attention to the distinction between a trance state and a no-trance state and asks whether we create it or is it simply happening to us. Towards the end of the text, the author establishes a context for the approach in relation to the field of psychotherapy and the Ericksonian model of hypnotherapy in particular.

last_phrase: In conclusion, interruptions of our natural state of thought, feeling, sensation or physical movement can lead to neurosis, caused by our judgments and internal censor. By learning to observe and develop our awareness through meditation, we can become more conscious of our trance states and move beyond them. Erickson's naturalistic approaches to hypnotherapy and Eastern perspectives offer complementary puzzle pieces to this paradigmatic shift in psychotherapy.
